author: Christie Blatchford
title: Christie Blatchford: Quebec premier strikes perfect balance of sorrow and strength after mosque shooting | National Post
text:
Quebec City mosque attack victims shot in the back as they prayed: 'We have a sadness we cannot express' 
Here, he was not urging censorship, not even self-censorship, but rather kindness to others and care with facts. 
Asked if he feared the attack, which left six dead and another 19 wounded, two critically, was a result of the mood created by new U.S. President Donald Trump, Couillard said, “I would not go there” and that it was too soon to know “what kind of horrible message” the attack was meant to send. 
He added, “This is why our country has to remain a beacon” of tolerance and welcoming. 
It was easier, he admitted, to speak like this now, in the thick of the awfulness. “The real challenge will be two weeks from now.” 
And in the Trump era, which thus far has been marked by hyperbole, florid generalizations about Muslims and Mexicans and some spectacularly bonehead decisions — Trump’s press secretary said of the mosque attack, “it’s a terrible reminder of why we must remain vigilant,” though vigilant about quite what threat is hardly clear — Couillard was determinedly mild. 
Yes, he acknowledged, the same devils that haunt every society — “xenophobia, racism, exclusion” — are present here, but Quebec and Canada remain “a good, generally loving society.” 
“We are envied by the whole world,” Couillard said. “Hence the dismay we see today.” 
It’s important, he said, to always “use two verbs in the same sentence — fight and prevent,” fight terrorism, and also prevent people from feeling excluded. 
The premier stood Monday at a press conference in Quebec City beside Mohamed Labidi, the dear broken man who is vice-president of the mosque and who knew some of the victims. 
Couillard was the very picture of gentleness. He even helped translate into English what Labidi was saying through his tears. He looked like he wanted to take him into his arms. 
There were others who have said the right things, among them Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, the opposition leaders, the Robin Williams-esque Quebec City Mayor, Régis Labeaume, the smart young Liberal MP for the area, Joel Lightbound. 
But Couillard was the giant, happy to admit ours isn’t a perfect society, but damn sure it’s worth the fight to keep. I thought he was magnificent. 
At the end of the presser, he said “We are all Quebecois. 
“Once we say this, then we talk to each other. 
“Next time you walk past someone of the Muslim community, why don’t you stop and say hello?” 
Then all the people who had spoken this day held hands as one of them sang a prayer, in Arabic. 
In a fractured world, it sounded lovely, and just right.
